description: The Continual Service Improvement module focuses on how organizations and individuals can strategically review the products and services they have produced following the strategy, design, transition and operation stages of the IT Service Lifecycle and offers guidance on how this process should be organized and executed. It also includes guidance on the tools and technology that can be used to support CSI activities as well as how to evaluate risks and critical success factors.
descriptionMD: ** Look for our partner PassionIT Group's information [HERE](https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/ITIL_OVERVIEW.zip)  Codes for offers are available to members and in the download in the second episode** The Continual Service Improvement module focuses on how organizations and individuals can strategically review the products and services they have produced following the strategy, design, transition and operation stages of the IT Service Lifecycle and offers guidance on how this process should be organized and executed. It also includes guidance on the tools and technology that can be used to support CSI activities as well as how to evaluate risks and critical success factors. For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please [contact PassionIT Group](mailto:info@passionitgroup.com).
name: Accredited ITIL Intermediate - CSI
subtitle: Continual Service Improvement

episodes.description: For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group info@passionitgroup.com.The Continual Service Improvement module focuses on how organizations and individuals can strategically review the products and services they have produced following the strategy, design, transition and operation stages of the IT Service Lifecycle and offers guidance on how this process should be organized and executed. It also includes guidance on the tools and technology that can be used to support CSI activities as well as how to evaluate risks and critical success factors.
episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.717
[SOUND] Hi and welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:05.717 --> 00:00:07.431
My name is Jo Peacock and

3
00:00:07.431 --> 00:00:13.190
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL intermediate.

4
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:18.520
So let's take a look then at
our first slide here coming up.

5
00:00:18.520 --> 00:00:23.840
And we have our introduction
to our intermediate class and

6
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming intermediate class.

7
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.745
You will see what we will cover is
an introduction to the class followed

8
00:00:32.745 --> 00:00:37.112
by the principles and
the processes of the lifecycle phase.

9
00:00:37.112 --> 00:00:40.907
Then we'll take a look at organizing for
that lifecycle phase and

10
00:00:40.907 --> 00:00:43.500
also the technology considerations.

11
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:48.270
Especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

12
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:51.880
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and the critical success factors and

13
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:57.110
all of the risks that are associated
with that particular lifecycle phase.

14
00:00:57.110 --> 00:01:00.692
And most importantly, of course,
for you, is that preparation for

15
00:01:00.692 --> 00:01:04.543
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class.

16
00:01:04.543 --> 00:01:07.142
Okay, so let me take a look now then and

17
00:01:07.142 --> 00:01:11.790
how we're going to approach this
particular intermediate class.

18
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work,

19
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.550
obviously you're going to be watching us
on-screen both myself and my colleagues,

20
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:27.110
and we're going to be taking you through
the course materials for the class.

21
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:31.450
And then there are going to be some
discussions and some exercises that

22
00:01:31.450 --> 00:01:38.140
are going to be based primarily in our
chat rooms and also in our forums as well.

23
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.530
And we're also available if you want
to undertake any of the assessments,

24
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:45.960
then please feel free to come
back to us via the forums and

25
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.270
we will be able to help
you out in any way we can.

26
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:51.950
Also provided in the course material,
which is available for

27
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:57.390
you to download, are mock tests or
exams if you prefer to use that word.

28
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:02.720
And we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you.

29
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.675
So, where are we then at
ITIL intermediate level?

30
00:02:08.675 --> 00:02:15.090
Well, you'll see in using Bloomâ€™s Taxonomy
that we are actually at Level 4 Analyzing.

31
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:19.931
In other words, we've done foundation
level, we've done the remembering and

32
00:02:19.931 --> 00:02:23.007
the understanding of those
concepts within ITIL.

33
00:02:23.007 --> 00:02:26.361
And we're actually moving
through applying those

34
00:02:26.361 --> 00:02:29.020
concepts to analyzing those concepts.

35
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:32.809
And being able to apply
the ITIL processes, and

36
00:02:32.809 --> 00:02:38.787
also the concepts at a real world level,
in a real world situation, okay?

37
00:02:38.787 --> 00:02:42.171
So where does ITIL come from then?

38
00:02:42.171 --> 00:02:45.080
Well let me give you a little
bit of a background.

39
00:02:45.080 --> 00:02:48.812
It's actually owned by
a company called Axelos and

40
00:02:48.812 --> 00:02:53.771
it was first published in the mid 1980s,
by the UK government.

41
00:02:53.771 --> 00:03:00.665
And the Office of Government Commerce
owned ITIL for a very, very long time.

42
00:03:00.665 --> 00:03:04.915
And we developed ITIL right
the way back from the 1980s,

43
00:03:04.915 --> 00:03:08.999
through its version 2 in the 1990s,
mid 1990s,

44
00:03:08.999 --> 00:03:12.271
to version 3 which was released in 2007.

45
00:03:12.271 --> 00:03:17.620
And then there was an update
to version 3 in 2011,

46
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:22.450
which is exactly where we are right now.

47
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.660
It is copyright, it is trademark
protected, it's a framework for

48
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:28.670
managing services.

49
00:03:28.670 --> 00:03:31.928
And as such, it is a flexible framework,

50
00:03:31.928 --> 00:03:37.796
a framework that we would expect any
organization to adopt as a framework,

51
00:03:37.796 --> 00:03:41.443
but then to adapt it to suit your needs,
okay?

52
00:03:41.443 --> 00:03:45.117
ITIL was born right
the way back in the 1980s,

53
00:03:45.117 --> 00:03:49.405
out of a desire to be able to
demonstrate value for money and

54
00:03:49.405 --> 00:03:54.340
efficiency for
the use of taxpayer's money within the UK.

55
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.860
Way back in the 1980s these things
started appearing on desks and

56
00:03:58.860 --> 00:04:03.880
quite frankly, we didn't know how
to manage these in an unbiased,

57
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:07.883
in an impartial and
in an efficient and effective way.

58
00:04:07.883 --> 00:04:13.009
And thus ITIL was born, and ITIL was
born from a group of industry experts

59
00:04:13.009 --> 00:04:18.305
that went out into the big wide world and
analysed various organizations,

60
00:04:18.305 --> 00:04:23.098
from various different industry sectors,
not just government but

61
00:04:23.098 --> 00:04:26.990
we're talking finance,
we're talking retail etc.

62
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:31.040
And they came back with
a set of best practices,

63
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:38.045
best practices that they observed in the
real world for managing our IT services.

64
00:04:38.045 --> 00:04:42.654
And thus, we have ITIL and
as I've already said we've had

65
00:04:42.654 --> 00:04:47.940
subsequent revisions and
now we're up to version 3, 2011.

66
00:04:47.940 --> 00:04:52.724
So we work on the understanding that we

67
00:04:52.724 --> 00:04:57.361
have a life to every single service.

68
00:04:57.361 --> 00:05:01.715
And we start off with a concept
in service strategy and

69
00:05:01.715 --> 00:05:07.600
then we take that concept and
we design it and then we develop it.

70
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:12.791
And we deploy it as a service into a live
environment which is where we operate and

71
00:05:12.791 --> 00:05:14.273
where we maintain it.

72
00:05:14.273 --> 00:05:19.040
And we continually seek to
ensure that we are aligned with

73
00:05:19.040 --> 00:05:22.230
the needs of the organization in CSI.

74
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:29.320
So you're attending this class
because you probably want to

75
00:05:29.320 --> 00:05:33.031
achieve an ITIL
Intermediate Qualification.

76
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.920
So you can that,
if we were to start off right at the very,

77
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.280
very top, you'll see where I am.

78
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer, working
with an accredited training organization.

79
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:52.830
I'm also an accredited examiner, and
proctor, or invigilator for these exams.

80
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:57.020
And work very, very closely with
the official ITIL accreditor and

81
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.560
also Axelos who owns the ITIL copyright.

82
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:07.080
Now in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

83
00:06:07.080 --> 00:06:09.058
Well, we start off with ITIL Foundation.

84
00:06:09.058 --> 00:06:14.103
And ITIL Foundation would
traditionally be a three day

85
00:06:14.103 --> 00:06:19.927
classroom experience where we
learn the foundations of ITIL.

86
00:06:19.927 --> 00:06:23.542
And we learn all the terminology, and all
of the definitions to that terminology.

87
00:06:23.542 --> 00:06:28.900
There's roughly around about 75 that we
learn within the ITIL Foundation class.

88
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:31.560
And then, as we move through we can

89
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:36.710
either take an ITIL practitioner class
which can be taken at any point in time,

90
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:40.820
throughout the progression
of your career within ITIL.

91
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:46.220
Because ITIL practitioner focuses on
the implementation of ITIL, okay?

92
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.210
Whereas if we take a look at the more
advanced intermediate classes,

93
00:06:50.210 --> 00:06:55.048
you are at this moment
in a Lifecycle Modules.

94
00:06:55.048 --> 00:06:59.720
And those Lifecycle Modules consist
of service strategy, service design,

95
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:04.470
service transition, service operation and
continual service improvement.

96
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:08.557
And that's where we focus on those
lifecycles that we've just looked at

97
00:07:08.557 --> 00:07:09.367
previously.

98
00:07:09.367 --> 00:07:14.776
Okay, and on the right hand side
then we have our capability modules,

99
00:07:14.776 --> 00:07:20.590
and these capability modules really
focus on specific areas within ITIL.

100
00:07:20.590 --> 00:07:27.109
Such as, RCV which focuses on
release control and validation.

101
00:07:27.109 --> 00:07:30.504
And these classes,
you will notice that every single

102
00:07:30.504 --> 00:07:34.430
one of these classes has got
a score right beside each one.

103
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.271
So we've got a number 2 for
ITIL Foundation and we've got a 3 for

104
00:07:39.271 --> 00:07:44.213
Lifecycle Modules and we've got a 4 for
our Capability Modules.

105
00:07:44.213 --> 00:07:49.383
Now what we need to do is
ensure that we have achieved

106
00:07:49.383 --> 00:07:54.674
a minimum of 15 credits at
both either lifecycle or

107
00:07:54.674 --> 00:07:57.460
capability module level.

108
00:07:57.460 --> 00:08:03.252
In order to be able to qualify to sit the
Managing Across the Lifecycle class and

109
00:08:03.252 --> 00:08:08.665
therefore subsequently the test
that goes along with that class.

110
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:13.065
So we need to take two from the ITIL
Foundation, that's a prerequisite,

111
00:08:13.065 --> 00:08:14.905
we have to do the foundation.

112
00:08:14.905 --> 00:08:19.756
And then we need to add in another
15 scores from either, as I've said,

113
00:08:19.756 --> 00:08:22.511
the lifecycle or the capability stream.

114
00:08:22.511 --> 00:08:25.549
Now you can interchange,
you can mix and match,

115
00:08:25.549 --> 00:08:29.100
you do not have to stick to one stream or
the other.

116
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.215
Once you've got that 17 in total scores

117
00:08:33.215 --> 00:08:37.165
that are needed to be able to sit
Managing across The Lifecycle.

118
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:40.805
You're perfectly able to sit
that lifecycle class and

119
00:08:40.805 --> 00:08:43.503
to be able to take that test afterwards.

120
00:08:43.503 --> 00:08:48.542
And as soon as you've take that test,
you will be awarded those 5 credits,

121
00:08:48.542 --> 00:08:52.535
which will mean that you
have achieved ITIL Expert.

122
00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:57.073
Now, ITIL Expert is allocated
as soon as you have passed

123
00:08:57.073 --> 00:09:02.510
the Managing Across the Lifecycle test and
have achieved 22 credits.

124
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:05.770
Both of those must happen in order for
you to achieve ITIL Expert.

125
00:09:07.380 --> 00:09:10.090
Now, we have the ITIL Master
qualification,

126
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:14.630
and the ITIL Master is
a completely different beast.

127
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.410
The ITIL Master is a two-year
qualification, and

128
00:09:19.410 --> 00:09:25.750
during that two years you will be
expected to submit various white papers

129
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:31.500
on specific topics within
the ITIL qualification scheme.

130
00:09:31.500 --> 00:09:35.870
So these could be topics
on activities within ITIL,

131
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.830
these could be topics on
processes within ITIL,

132
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.810
these could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

133
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:46.860
But you will be required to sit
a number of white papers or

134
00:09:46.860 --> 00:09:51.410
submit a number of white papers
over the period of two years.

135
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.520
At the end of those two years,
once you have submitted the prerequisite

136
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

137
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:06.760
And during that panel interview, you will
be assessed not only on your white papers,

138
00:10:06.760 --> 00:10:11.880
but also on your experience within
the IT service management arena.

139
00:10:11.880 --> 00:10:13.890
And at the end of that panel interview,

140
00:10:13.890 --> 00:10:18.630
then if successful, you will be
awarded the status of ITIL Master.

141
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:24.735
So the qualification scheme, I'm going to
take this back now to Bloom's Taxonomy

142
00:10:24.735 --> 00:10:28.969
then and just very, very quickly look
at the fact that in ITIL Foundation.

143
00:10:28.969 --> 00:10:32.661
And I know that I've already
covered this on a previous slide,

144
00:10:32.661 --> 00:10:36.774
we just looked at understanding,
understanding the terminology and

145
00:10:36.774 --> 00:10:39.150
the concepts of ITIL Foundation.

146
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:43.954
And then in the Lifecycle Modules we're
looking at implementing those processes

147
00:10:43.954 --> 00:10:45.423
contained within ITIL.

148
00:10:45.423 --> 00:10:50.148
And in Capability we're looking at
actually undertaking those process and

149
00:10:50.148 --> 00:10:51.928
managing those processes.

150
00:10:51.928 --> 00:10:57.446
Whereas Managing Across the Lifecycle,
this is for senior management,

151
00:10:57.446 --> 00:11:01.639
this is at CIO level, and
its senior management level.

152
00:11:01.639 --> 00:11:05.179
And in MALC,
as we like to abbreviate it to,

153
00:11:05.179 --> 00:11:10.475
you're concerned with leading
IT service management.

154
00:11:10.475 --> 00:11:15.262
So I mentioned right at the very
beginning of all of this that we had

155
00:11:15.262 --> 00:11:20.240
a test to go along with every single
lifecycle phase, and there is.

156
00:11:20.240 --> 00:11:25.176
And we will be conducting a session
to go over this particular test or

157
00:11:25.176 --> 00:11:27.600
at least a sample of these tests,

158
00:11:27.600 --> 00:11:32.960
just to give you some preparation for
the actual test itself.

159
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:38.678
So your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually.

160
00:11:38.678 --> 00:11:46.390
It is an 8 multiple choice question test,
it's complex multiple choice.

161
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:48.829
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test.

162
00:11:48.829 --> 00:11:54.054
And with every single question,
you will be given a scenario and

163
00:11:54.054 --> 00:11:59.958
then you will be given four possible
options, four possible answers for

164
00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.331
the question that is posed
along with that scenario.

165
00:12:04.331 --> 00:12:10.410
You get 5 points for the best fit answer,
now it mentions up there the most correct.

166
00:12:10.410 --> 00:12:13.910
I always call it the best fit,
because every single question asks

167
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:19.300
what is the best answer given
the scenario and given the question?

168
00:12:19.300 --> 00:12:24.860
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct,

169
00:12:24.860 --> 00:12:28.480
because the question is asking you for
the best fit.

170
00:12:28.480 --> 00:12:32.800
And for that best fit you're
gonna get 5 points, for

171
00:12:32.800 --> 00:12:37.696
the next best fit you're gonna get 3,
for the next one which

172
00:12:37.696 --> 00:12:42.897
we've considered to be the least
correct you're gonna get 1.

173
00:12:42.897 --> 00:12:47.890
And for the next one you're gonna get a 0,
now it mentions up on that

174
00:12:47.890 --> 00:12:52.021
slide there that the next one
is 0 marks for incorrect.

175
00:12:52.021 --> 00:12:56.490
We like to call that in the industry, us
in the know, we call that the distractor.

176
00:12:56.490 --> 00:13:00.600
And we call it the distractor for
a reason, cuz it distracts.

177
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:04.130
And quite often what you will find is,
with your distractor,

178
00:13:04.130 --> 00:13:08.440
a lot of the words in the terminology that
are taken straight out of the ITIL books,

179
00:13:08.440 --> 00:13:10.790
straight out of the publications, and

180
00:13:10.790 --> 00:13:15.490
are input into that 0 pointer
because it's there to distract.

181
00:13:15.490 --> 00:13:21.250
And it sounds great, but more often
than not, that distractor has absolutely

182
00:13:21.250 --> 00:13:26.600
no relevance to the scenario or
to the question.

183
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:31.480
So you have to be incredibly careful with
that, it's so easy to be distracted.

184
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:38.370
You have to get 28 out of a possible
40 in order to be able to pass and

185
00:13:38.370 --> 00:13:44.540
achieve accreditation at
any lifecycle test, okay?

186
00:13:44.540 --> 00:13:48.960
If English is not your first language you
are allowed a paper dictionary, but you

187
00:13:48.960 --> 00:13:55.650
will be asked to show that to the proctor
at the time that you take your test.

188
00:13:55.650 --> 00:14:01.648
And as I've already said, you have to
have an ITIL Foundation in version 3 or

189
00:14:01.648 --> 00:14:08.225
version 3 2011, or an ITIL version 2
Foundation Bridge to version 3, okay?

190
00:14:08.225 --> 00:14:13.287
I will be very, very honest with you,
there are not that many

191
00:14:13.287 --> 00:14:18.580
people that have attained
the version 2 to version 3 Bridge.

192
00:14:18.580 --> 00:14:23.350
And most people will have the version 3 or

193
00:14:23.350 --> 00:14:27.540
2011, sorry, ITIL Foundation certificate.

194
00:14:27.540 --> 00:14:31.730
You will be required to
upload that certificate to

195
00:14:31.730 --> 00:14:36.510
the examining board prior to
sitting your lifecycle test.

196
00:14:36.510 --> 00:14:40.680
So be prepared with that,
you will need to have it to hand and

197
00:14:40.680 --> 00:14:42.590
saved as a PDF as well.

198
00:14:44.250 --> 00:14:51.880
So when we come to the end of every single
lifecycle class, we will be going over and

199
00:14:51.880 --> 00:14:56.410
this one's no exception,
we'll be going over a sample test for you.

200
00:14:56.410 --> 00:14:59.670
And during that sample test I'll
be giving you lots of hints and

201
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.150
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

202
00:15:04.150 --> 00:15:08.300
And also how to ensure that you read
the full question, how to relax and

203
00:15:08.300 --> 00:15:13.200
to make sure that you approach
it with an open mind, but

204
00:15:13.200 --> 00:15:16.100
you consider relevance
in every single answer.

205
00:15:17.590 --> 00:15:21.610
Ultimately, we wanna get you
past the test just as much as

206
00:15:21.610 --> 00:15:23.760
you want to achieve that accreditation.

207
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:30.608
So just to sum up, what we will
be doing over the next few shows

208
00:15:30.608 --> 00:15:37.255
is encouraging you to take your ITIL
lifecycle intermediate classes.

209
00:15:37.255 --> 00:15:41.289
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

210
00:15:41.289 --> 00:15:41.789
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement.  She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management.  Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective.  She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes.  Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the objectives and scope of CSI.  Jo makes sure that we understand the objective of CSI is to allow the organization to constantly see and improve all service lifecycles for the business.  She also discusses the business values of CSI to the business.
episodes.title: CSI Scope and Objectives

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the CSI Approach.  Jo discusses that the approach helps to set short term improvements and thereby help to also set long term CSI goals as well.  She also takes some time to review the service lifecycles that CSI will be a part.
episodes.title: CSI Scope and Objectives Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into some CSI principles.  Jo tells us about the keys to success of CSI and recommended use of Kotterâ€™s 8 step to transformational changes.  She also discusses the need for the responsible person for CSI and the authoritative person for CSI.  Another factor to keep CSI on track is the use of the csi registerâ€”a list of improvement opportunities that give everyone a voice to recommend an improvement too.  Lastly, she describes the how SLM and DIKW play a role in CSI success.
episodes.title: CSI Principles

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with additional CSI principles.  These include using the Demming Cycle for repeatable ongoing improvement, using service measurements like baseline, governance (control with transparency), frameworks and models, according to Jo.  Jo also mentions the push to standardization can help too!
episodes.title: CSI Principles Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the Seven Step Improvement Process at a high level overview.  Jo explains the key to making CSI a reality revolve around the consistency in our approach to CSI.  She reviews the basic concepts and principles that should be included and shows how these 7 activities become inputs toward the rest of ITIL.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the 7 step improvement process in more depth.  Jo dives into identifying the strategy by asking the questions of what are we trying to achieve and what will happen if we do not improve.  She continues with defining what we want to measure and what we can measure.  Jo also helps us to under the gathering of data and use of monitoring technology metrics, process metrics and service metrics.  Then lastly, she identifies the processing of data.  She discusses the frequency, format and accuracy of the processing.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the with some of the other activities in the 7 step improvement process.  Jo begins with explains analyzing data and information in CSI.  She discusses the usage of reports to help make more informed decisions.  Lastly, she discusses implementing improvements.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the how the the other Service Lifecycle Phase provides the input for CSI.  She also discusses the different management activities that help with different part os the 7 step improvement process.  Jo discusses the csfs and kpis along with the challenges and risk of CSI Integration.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Jo take a look at using a CSI technique of assessments.  She describes the purpose, the usage and output of assessments.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Assessments

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the use of benchmarks as leverage for CSI.  Jo explains that benchmarks are comparisons agains the norm or even an industry standard.  This is a competitive comparison that can be used to trigger CSI according to Jo.  She also explains that benchmarks help to keep our company aligned not only with business values but also with legislative demands and competitor performance.  She makes sure to emphasize that benchmarks do not help us to see where we need to be but only where we are in comparison to competitors and the standards.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Benchmarks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Joe discuss service measurement.  Jo reminds that customers to the service are rarely concerned about the details of how the service works they are concerned with end result.  This is what we must measure according to Jo.  Availability and reliability and performance are key measurements that we must measure.  These service measures provide validation, justification, direction and intervention.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Service Measurements

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo describe the use of the balanced scorescard, swot analysis and ROI.  Jo explains the balanced scorecard provides metrics from all perspectives.  She also explains the use of SWOT analysis and then how ROI and VOI different and measured.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Scorecard, SWOT and ROI

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss availability management.  Jo discusses that it begins with identifying SPoFs and evaluating them in terms of risks.  Also she describes the CFIA which helps to identify potential point of failure before they occur.  She contrasts this with FTA which is based on technology and topology that looks at the past.  Jo also describes SFA to help with end to end service availability and the Expanded incident Lifecycleâ€”Detect,Diagnose,Repair, Recover and Restoration).
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - CSI and Availability Mgmt

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss identifying and implementing improvement.  According to Jo, there are many management processes  that might be considered when implementing improvements including capacity management, component capacity management, service capacity management, and business capacity management.  Alao described by Jo would be demand management and knowledge management.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - CSI and Lifecycle Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the idea of accountability and responsibility is the key to organizing for CSI.  Jo states that itâ€™s import for an organization to define the process owner and manager.  She also emphasizes the need for these roles to be filled with skilled people who can do analysis, reporting and knows additional frameworks to get things done.  The example Jo provides is using a RACI chart as an example.
episodes.title: Organizing for CSI

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo talk about some of the technology considerations to help with CSI.  Jo lets us know that a single tool may be the way to go but we may find out the cost may outweigh the technology we already have.  She tells us the key is to ensure that those technologies should be inter-related to provide what the user needs.  The technologies to help with CSI should help us to identify, track and validate the improvements we need to make, the progress of the improvement and the result of that improvement.
episodes.title: Technology Considerations for CSI

episodes.description: aIn this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin with discussing the implementation and communication.  Jo emphasizes the formalization of the communication plan and helps us to know where to begin implementing CSI.  She tells us to pick a pain point to start.  She also mentions the use of CoBIT and ITIL together to know what needs to be achieved to improve and ITIL shows us how.
episodes.title: Implementation and Communication

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look at the challenges to implementing CSI, the CSFs that show what needs to be accomplished and then the risks that can stop of CSI in its progress.  Jo reviews the most common factors in each of these areas to help us gain a better understanding of the CSI lifecycle.
episodes.title: Challenges, CSFs and Risks

episodes.description: For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group info@passionitgroup.com. In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review some of the different techniques and details when sitting for your ITIL Intermediate exam.  They recommend downloading the sample paper for review.  Jo reviews the details on scoring of the exam.  She also has solid exam advice for delegates preparing for an exam.
episodes.title: Exam Review Introduction

episodes.description: Exam Review for ITIL Intermediate CSI
episodes.title: Exam Review

episodes.description: Exam Review for ITIL Intermediate CSI
episodes.title: Exam Review Part 2
